details.title: Combined k-out-of-n:G, and consecutive k/sub c/-out-of-n:G systems
details.standardTitle: Combined k-out-of-n:G, and consecutive k/sub c/-out-of-n:G systems

p: Amos Eliahu Gera received the B.Sc. from Hebrew University, Jerusalem, and the M.Sc. and Ph.D. in Applied Mathematics from the Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel. His thesis was related to the design of feedback controllers for systems with large parameter uncertainties. He joined ELTA Systems Ltd. in 1981. His topics of interest belong to the areas of reliability engineering, antenna theory and electromagnetics, and feedback control.

authors.affiliation: Quality Manage. Div., ELTA Syst. Ltd., Ashdod, Israel
authors.name: A.E. Gera

details.abstract: Qualification tests for a system are normally carried out according to either a k-out-of-n:G scheme, or a consecutive k/sub c/-out-of-n:G structure. The reliability of a combination of the two systems is evaluated, showing its benefit over each of the individual structures. As expected, the mean time to failure of the combined system is larger than any of them. Generalizations of the analysis are presented for tests with multi-state results, and for dependent tests. Illustrative numerical results are presented to substantiate the theory.

citations.title: Combined k-out-of-n:G, and consecutive k/sub c/-out-of-n:G systems

links.abstract: The consecutive-k-out-of-n:F and related systems have caught the attention of many researchers since the early 1980s. The studies of these systems lead to better understanding of the reliability of general series systems, In computation and structure. This paper is mainly a chronological survey of computing the reliability of these systems.

references.title: IEEE Trans. Rel.
references.text: M. T. Chao, J. C. Fu, M. V. Koutras, IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-44, pp. 120-126, Mar. 1995.

links.abstract: A special communication system with moving relay stations is introduced in this paper. The relay stations are all moving at the same speed from an origin toward a destination. If k consecutive stations fail before the first station reaches the destination, all stations ahead of the k failed stations as well as the k failed stations are lost. The objective is to have one station reach the destination without k or more consecutive failed stations between the destination and the origin. When the st...

context.text: Following calculations performed by Chiang and Chiang [2], Papastavridis and Hadjichristos [10], and Zuo, Lin, and Wu [12], it is assumed that each test has an exponential lifetime distribution, and numerical examples will be provided to highlight this point.

references.text: D. T. Chiang, R. Chiang, "Relayed communication via consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-35, pp. 65-67, Apr. 1986.

links.abstract: Reliabilities are studied for consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems with component failures having (k-1)-step Markov dependence.

context.text: Papers by Fu [3], Papastavridis and Lambiris [11], and Gera [4] tackled this problem.

Although it is assumed within most of the references that the tests (components) are statistically independent, some work has been carried out for consecutive F:systems by Fu [3], and Papastavridis and Lambiris [11], to analyze possibly dependent tests.

context.text: The author has previously considered the possibility of three states of an individual test (success, failure, degradation) for consecutive \${\rm k}_{\rm c}\$-out-of-n:G systems [5].

references.text: A. E. Gera, "Accomodating degradation results within a qualification procedure", Reliab. Eng. Syst. Saf., vol. 72, pp. 103-109, 2001.

links.abstract: In a binary k-out-of-n:G system, k is the minimum number of components that must work for the system to work. Let 1 represent the working state and 0 the failure state, k then indicates the minimum number of components that must be in state 1 for the system to be in state 1. This paper defines the multi-state k-out-of-n:G system: each component and the system can be in 1 of M+1 possible states: 0, 1, ..., M. In Case I, the system is in state /spl ges/j iff at least k/sub j/ components are in sta...

context.text: An approach to deal with multi-state k-out-of-n:G systems has been recently presented by Huang, Zuo, and Wu [6].
Multi-state k-out-of-n:G systems have been dealt with in various publications [6], [7].

references.title: Generalized multi-state k-out-of-n:G systems
references.text: J. Huang, "Generalized multi-state k-out-of-n:G systems", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-49, pp. 105-111, Mar. 2000.

context.text: Recently, the possibility of combining the two requirements has been presented for F systems by Zuo, Lin, and Wu [12]; see also Kuo and Zuo [7], ch. 11.
A survey of multistate system models can be found in the book of Kuo and Zuo [7], ch. 12.
The reliability of the set of tests is derived from the equation [7], ch. 8, [12]for \${\rm i}=1,\ldots,{\rm n}\$; \${\rm j}=1,\ldots,{\rm k}\$ with boundary conditions:.
Under the same assumptions, the following recursive relation exists for \${\rm i}>{\rm j}_{\rm c}\$ [7], ch. 9, [12]:with boundary conditions.
The reliability of a combination of the above two systems has been calculated by Zuo, Liu, and Wu [12] (see also [7], ch. 11).
The following equation for G:systems is analogous to the one stated in [7], [12]:for \$1\leq {\rm j}\leq {\rm k}\$, \$1\leq{\rm i}\leq{\rm n}\$.
It is known (see for instance [7], p. 30) that the binomial distribution tends to a \$s\$-normal one as \${\rm n}\rightarrow\infty\$under the restrictions that ‘p’ and ‘q’ are not too small.
Multi-state k-out-of-n:G systems have been dealt with in various publications [6], [7].
A survey on this topic can be found in [7], ch. 9.

For the regular k-out-of-n problem, and assuming a Weibull distribution, the probability of success of a test at time ‘t’ is identical to the probability that the system can survive up to time ‘t’, and may be of the form (see [7], p. 104):.
The special case of the exponential distribution [7], p. 257 may be easily derived from (53).

references.title: Optimal Reliability Modeling, Principles and Applications
references.text: W. Kuo, M. J. Zuo, Optimal Reliability Modeling Principles and Applications, 2003.

links.abstract: A consecutive-k-out-of-n:F (consecutive-k-out-of-n:G) system consists of an ordered sequence of n components such that the system is failed (good) if and only if at least k consecutive components in the system are failed (good). In the present work, the relationship between the consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system and the consecutive-k-out-of-n:G system is studied, theorems for such systems are developed, and available results for one type of system are applied to the other. The topics include system...

references.title: A consecutive-k-out-of-n:G system: the mirror image of a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system
references.text: W. Kuo, "A consecutive-k-out-of-n:G system: the mirror image of a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-39, pp. 244-253, June 1990.

links.abstract: A consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system, with n linearly or circularly arranged i.i.d. components is examined. The system reliability has an exact formula which is straight forward and more effective than those given elsewhere; the two formulas are given.

context.text: Lambiris and Papastavridis [9] provided a closed-form solution for F:systems which is easily modified for G:systems.
Considering a consequential \${\rm k}_{\rm c}\$-out-of-n:G system of tests, the exact reliability formula of Lambiris and Papastavridis [9] may be used which acquires the formwhere Hence.

references.title: IEEE Trans. Rel.
references.text: M. Lambiris, S. Papastavridis, IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-34, pp. 124-126, June 1985.

links.abstract: A general formula is given for the mean time to failure of a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system with equal component-failure probabilities. The special case of Weibuil life distribution is examined.

context.text: Following calculations performed by Chiang and Chiang [2], Papastavridis and Hadjichristos [10], and Zuo, Lin, and Wu [12], it is assumed that each test has an exponential lifetime distribution, and numerical examples will be provided to highlight this point.
Utilizing the known integral [10]the MTTF of the k-out-of-n:G set of tests, assuming the probability of success of each test (49), is.

references.title: Mean time to failure for a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system
references.text: S. Papastavridis, J. Hadjichristos, "Mean time to failure for a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-36, pp. 85-86, Apr. 1987.

links.abstract: We examine a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system, where the probability of failure of a component depends upon the state, (good or failed) of the preceding component; ie, the states of the components form a Markov chain. We compute the reliability of such a system, via a recurrence relation.

context.text: Papers by Fu [3], Papastavridis and Lambiris [11], and Gera [4] tackled this problem.

Although it is assumed within most of the references that the tests (components) are statistically independent, some work has been carried out for consecutive F:systems by Fu [3], and Papastavridis and Lambiris [11], to analyze possibly dependent tests.
Under the special condition that one-step dependence is used, the following is a result of Papastavridis and Lambiris [11] for consecutive \${\rm k}_{\rm c}\$-out-of-n systems.

references.title: Reliability of a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system for Markov-dependent components
references.text: S. Papastavridis, M. Lambiris, "Reliability of a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system for Markov-dependent components", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-36, pp. 78-79, Apr. 1987.

links.abstract: Based on a real industrial application, three new system reliability models are proposed: combined k-out-of-n:F and consecutive-k/sub c/-out-of-n:F system; combined k-out-of-m/spl middot/n:F and linear connected-(r,s)-out-of-(m,n):F system; and combined k-out-of-m/spl middot/n:F consecutive-k/sub c/-out-of-n:F and linear connected-(r,s)-out-of-(m,n):F system. Reliability evaluation algorithms are provided for these models. The computation times of the algorithms for these models are, respectivel...

context.text: Recently, the possibility of combining the two requirements has been presented for F systems by Zuo, Lin, and Wu [12]; see also Kuo and Zuo [7], ch. 11.

Following calculations performed by Chiang and Chiang [2], Papastavridis and Hadjichristos [10], and Zuo, Lin, and Wu [12], it is assumed that each test has an exponential lifetime distribution, and numerical examples will be provided to highlight this point.
The reliability of the set of tests is derived from the equation [7], ch. 8, [12]for \${\rm i}=1,\ldots,{\rm n}\$; \${\rm j}=1,\ldots,{\rm k}\$ with boundary conditions:.
Under the same assumptions, the following recursive relation exists for \${\rm i}>{\rm j}_{\rm c}\$ [7], ch. 9, [12]:with boundary conditions.
The reliability of a combination of the above two systems has been calculated by Zuo, Liu, and Wu [12] (see also [7], ch. 11).
The following equation for G:systems is analogous to the one stated in [7], [12]:for \$1\leq {\rm j}\leq {\rm k}\$, \$1\leq{\rm i}\leq{\rm n}\$.

context.text: Because a regular assumption on the reliability of systems is that they have an exponential distribution, the chances of success of the relevant tests are exponentially distributed [13].
